sections.title: PART II: Counting Combinations I (3pts)
sections.instruction: Given the blocks below answer the following questions.

items.text: 5. How many different three-block towers can you make?
6. How many different three-block towers can you make if there is a restriction that the red block cannot be at the top?
7. How many different four-block towers can you make, if there is a restriction that the red block and the blue block cannot be at the top?

sections.title: PART III: Counting Combinations II (4pts)
sections.instruction:
Given the problem below, answer the following questions.

Suppose that the four-character code has the following restrictions:
- Numbers and letters
- Uppercase letters only (lowercase is not allowed)
- Cannot repeat characters

items.text: 8. What characters can make up the code?
9. How many possible characters are there for the first spot in the password?
10. How many possible characters are there for the fourth spot in the password?
11. How many total password combinations are possible?

sections.title: PART IV: Patterns in Mathematics (3pts)
sections.instruction: Given the two numbers, find the GCF (greatest common factor) using the specified method.

items.text: 12. Use the factorization method to find the GCF of **30** and **40**.
13. Use the subtraction method to find the GCF of **11** and **22**.
14. Use the division method to find the GCF of **77** and **49**.

sections.title: PART V: Graphs and Trees (6pts)
sections.instruction: Answer the following questions by selecting the correct answer.

items.text: 15. The highlighted part of the graph is called:
16. The highlighted part of the graph is called:
Use the graph below to answer the following questions.
17. Which node is the root?
options: Nodes E, F, G, H, I
Nodes E, F, C, G, H, I

items.text: 18. Which nodes are leaves?
options: Nodes E, F, G, H, I
Nodes E, F, C, G, H, I

items.text:
Draw a graph in the space below based on the information given and answer the questions.

In a class, there are five students: Fah, Beam, New, Win, and Tae.

Here is some information about their friendships:
- Fah is friends with Beam, New, and Win.
- Beam is friends with Tae.
- New is friends with Win and Tae.
- Win is friends with Tae.

Draw a graph to represent the friendships where:
- Each student is a node.
- Each friendship is an edge (a line connecting two students).
19. List the nodes of your graph (e.g. Mina):
20. List the edges of your graph (e.g. Fah - Beam):
